whiche inhabyted adioynynge alwayes theyr frendes corynthyans sett theyr matter order taken victuailes thre dayes departed nyght sayde promountory cymeriū comme fyght wyth ye corcyryens day sawe farre mayne sea comming ryght agaynst put selues battayle sydes made theyr order followeth corcyryens dyd put ryght syde tenne shyppes athene deuided thē selues thre bandes left syde euerye hauyng hys capitaine corinthian syde ambratiens magarens right winge middle allyes founde lefte wynge dyrectly agaynst ryght wynge corcyryens corinthiens theyr selues thys manner came one agaynste hauyng eyther sydes geuen token fyght aither bestowed great nombre archer well armed toppes shyppes vpon top castels euyll ynough appoynted fashyon tyme foughte verye sharpely arte dayes vpon sea hande hande wythout remouing fote men fyght mayne lande myngled together coulde well remoue thē selues droune one ye hope victory fought toppe castells rather thynge effecte fought strengthe courage connynge fight conflicte great shippes athens went succoure corcyryēs sawe thē ouercommed feare ennemyes yet dyd fyght agaynste fearyng disobeye commaundement theyr lordes chaunced corinthiens right wynge ouercharged theyr ennemies toke self vnto flight chased followed tenne shyppes corcyryens vntyll lande theyr campe landed thē suche sorte toke pillaged al found within afterwardes set fyer therin meane tyme occupyed chase pillage corinthiens y• left wynge hadde easely victory agaynst theyr ennemyes taried fought agaynst also stronger shyppes atheniās seynge corcyryens ouercharged put rebuke beganne succoure earnestly wythout dissymulation yet inuaded corinthian begynnyng sawe corcyryens flight chased bent selfe fyght resiste beste coulde wythoute makynge dyfference one necessytye requyred battaylle remayned betwene athenyans corynthyans corcyryans beyng flyght neuertheles last constrayned wythdrawe selues corinthyans followed chase taried bynde fasten theyr shyppes barkes shyppes beaten downe yet cause taken towed lande sayling chasynge indeuored themselues slaye ennemyes take alyue whiche doyng slewe many theyr frendes founde theyr waye vpon theyr shippes bottomes theyr syde bene dyscomfyted thinking bene enemyes great nomber shyppes beynge assembled aswell one syde grekes myngled togeder knewe well one coulde tell ouercommers ouercommed also truly greatest assemblye shyppes euer tymes paste bene made grekes agaynst grekes corinthian chased corcyriens entrye sea dyd retourne receyue shippwrackes shyppes skatered abroade brused also theyr people hurte founde greate nomber whiche brought vnto poorte oueranempste islande sybota fyrme lande holy deserte regyon thesphrotyde straungers comme theyr ayde dyd tary lāde bestowed theyr brused shyppes theyr hurte people sayled agayne shyppes hadde hoole go agaynst corcyre whiche seyng corcyriens came agaynst hole shippes athens lefte fearynge sayde corynthyaus wolde haue made entry lande nowit late nyght nowe begonne geue token woulde fyght whan corinthian perceyued farre sea twenty shyppes athenyans hadde sent freshe vnto corcyryans fearyng tēne sente furst suffycyent ynough saue defende lyke also chaunced occasyon thereof corinthian begonne take oores litle lytle retourne backe principally knewe whyther came greater nomber sawe whereat corcyryens coulde yet see theyr sayd succoure abasshedde seing theyr ennemyes retourne coulde thinke wherfore vntyll theyr people perceyued sayd twenty shyppes signifyed came directly vnto beyng nowe also night corcyryens lykewyse wythdrewe themselues thys manner hauyng foughte vnto darke night departed anone sayde twenty shippes aryued porte leucine corcyryens wythdrawen passynge ouer deade broken peces shyppes brused drowned twenty shyppes glaucō sōne leager andocydes sonne leogorus conducte glaucō andocides night corcyryens furste burnte doubte bene ennemys hauynge certen knowlayge receyued greate ioye morowe thirty shyppes athenyans wyth lefte hoole vnto corcyryens wente poorte wyth theyr sayles displayed came agaynst porte sibota corinthian see yf would come agayne battayle whan sawe come departed frō porte mayne sea good order kepte themself sure defende willing go assayle thē feared sayde shyppes newely comme freshe hoole theyrs greatly hurte empayred battayle day theyr people busyed kepe prysonners taken sayde battaile also coulde refreshe themselues wyth thynge place sibota deserte barayne cared howe might honnestly wythdrawe self theyr quarter fearyng athenyans wolde suffer departe thence vnder coulour hadde broken peace came assayle thē daye deuysed sende vpon brygantyne theyr people towardes sayde athenyans withoute heraulte espye wolde spake vnto thē maner agaynst reasone lordes atheniens begynne warre vpon v commyng directly agaynst treatie peace haue togidres let v maye chastyse oure subiectes yf deliberated empesthe v maye go agaynst corcyryens ell woll meane declare selues ennemyes beginne v intreat v enemy wordes corcyryēs coulde vnderstande beganne crye wt one voice yt shuld taken slaine incontinētly athenian aunswered thē manner lordes peloponesians perceyue haue broken treatie peace whiche haue youe comme hyther fyghte wyth youe onely defende kepe corcyryens oure allyes wherfore yf youe woll go anye elles theyr lande woll trouble youe yf come endomage theyme woll defende power aunswere receyued corynthians prepared self retourne vnto house theyr departure sett vp theyr trophee token victory firme lande sibota theyr departynge corcyryens gathered togeder theyr brokenne shyppes deade people whome wynde marreys nyght dryuē shore sea euen aryued afterwardes set vp trophee signe victory islande sibota directly agaynste corinthian bothe party pretended haue victory wytt corinthian yt kepte sea vntyll nyght gathered many shipwrackes shippes drowned also great nomber deade people taken thousande prysonners drowned aboutes threskoore tenne shippes ennemys corcyryens capytaynes wyth xxx shippes armed make warre coū trey macedonie commaūded thē passyng shuld take pleadges thē potide beate downe theyr walle furthermore shulde take good hede cytyes dyd rebelle whiche vnderstandynge potydyans sente theyr cytezeins athens see yf coulde obteigne wolde nouueltie syde sente wyth corynthians lacedemonye haue counsaille comforte perswaded shulde prepare defende themselues yf anye woulde constrayne declared duryng tyme ambassadours gone athens lēgth shewed debated theyr case obteigned litle pre • ence despatched thyrty shippes sente agaynste perdicas agaynst calcydes perdicas perswaded shulde habandone forsake theyr townes hadde shore sea defensyble shulde wythdrawe self cytye olynthe standeth inner lande shulde fortefye aswell could vnto habandoned theyr taken towne arryualle seynge coulde wente lande marchedde strayght fourth agaynst potyde hauyng theyr hole armye thre thousande foote men aswell theyr people theyr cōfederates sixe houndred horse men macedonyens lxx shyppes whiche came coastynge lande suche manner iourneyed easely thyrd day arryued place grigronegigonum planted theyr campe potydians aristeus theyr people vnderstandyng commynge athenyans wente oute cytye came sett theyr campe cytye olyntheolynthus vpon distrayct kepyng theyr marcket wythoute towne wyth one accorde dyd chose aristeus capytaine foote men perdicas horseman incontynentlye appoinctement made wyth athenyans rebelled agaynste sente horseman succoure sayde potydians whome geuē charge iolausiolaus hys lieutenant opynyon aristeus tary athenyans wt bende sayde strayte mē muste force passe come potyde lande yf wolde comme thyder assayle calcydes wyth confederate wtout straycte also horseman perdicas shulde tary within towne olynthe ende yf athenyans came assaulte shulde come fourthe hys succour enclose sayde athenian theyr backes syde callia capytayne athenyens hys compaignyons sent theyr horsmen macedonyens certayne nomber footemē olynthe kepe within shulde come fourth succour remaynant went directly agaīste potyde nygh straicte seyng ennemys prepared selfe fight put selues lykewyse order came incontinently battayle aristeus hī aswell corinthiens good warryours dyd dryue backe putt flight formerwarde ennemys came agaynst thē gaue chase long way • poinct potydiens peloponesians athenyans vainquyshed chased gate towne seyng aristeus retourned fro chase great doubte two place might retyre potyde olynthe fynally determyned wtdrawe himselfe people yt might ioigne agayne hys wtin potyde yt nexte retrecte went sea beate walles towne betwene manye great stone set afore breake wawes sea passed right great dangier many throwes enemy dyd cast agaīst wherby thē slayne part entred towne nowe come fourth succour potydyans within olynthe situated high place wythout destrayte distant frō place battaille fought aboutes six thousande pas horseman macedoniens came agaynste thē dryue thē backe towne sawe atheniens hadde victory sixe houndred men ouerronne countreys calcide beoce toke castells suche quarells betwene athenyans peloponesyans corynthyans sorye athenyans troubled citie potide toke theyr part theyr cytezeynes peloponesians wythin athenyans complayned corynthyans caused potydiens whiche theyr subiectes rebelle come theyr ayde defend warre yet fully declared respitt questyon yet generallye agaynste peloponesians onely agaynste corinthiens alwayes fearynge losse potyde theyr people within dyd cease practyse theyr allyes come towardes lacedemonyens whiche theyr heade make theyr complayntes agaynste athenyans breaker peace ennemys peloponesians whiche dyd syde agenytes came thyder publiquely openly durste feare athenyans secretely perswaded warre dyd complayned athenyans wolde suffre enioye lybertye appoynted sayde treatye peace ambassadours confederated townes whiche comme thys matter arryued lacedemonye lacedemonyens assembled theyr counsayle caused declared wyth loude voyce yf parsonne pretended make complaincte agaynst athenyans shulde speake publiquely custome whiche admonytion came almost confederate peloponese makynge theyr complainctes doleances besydes megarens complayned beynge vnder seigniorye athenyans prohybited vse marchaundyse theyr porte theyr terrytorye corinthian laste suffred speake sett purpose prouoke get lacedemonyans afterwardes spake manner ¶the narration proposition corinthian counsaylle lacedemonye agaynste athenyans vii chapter fayth loyaultie youe kepe amonge aswell commun particuler lordes lacedemonyās maketh yf v shulde saye thynge agaynste man wolde beleue hym youre modestye loyaultie causeth youe esteamed youe vse one greate ignoraunce touchynge thynges wythoute albeit haue often shewed preached howe athenyans woulde ouercomme oppresse v yet woulde neuer beleue v shewed vnto youe sh • lde saye meanes particuler questyons meane therof wolde assemble allyes oultraged wronged youe haue forborne vntyll thys presente iniuryed therfor reasonable presence youre sayde allyes confederate make longer proposityon much dowbly offended wytt athenyans haue oultraged v youe haue regarded yf reasone whereby man myght defende • holye notoryous athenyans whiche trouble grece requysitt shulde cause appere vnto knowe nedeth nowe holde longer purpose sythens youe may see one brought seruitude athenian sharply assaulted specyally yt allyes long saisone haue imagyned wtdrawe vnto serue ayde thē agaynst v time warre truly warre made agaynst thē certaynly haue none purpose occupyed corcyre holde potyde assiged wherof one witt corcyre shulde fournyshe peloponesians greate nomber shyppes y propice affayres thrace whych thinges arne blamed begynnynge whan warre medes fynyshed suffred make thair cytie agayne afterwardes moreouer increase yt wyth greate walles successiuely tyme vnto presente daye haue tolerated suffred depriue lybertye putt bondage thair allyes onely also beyt may well sayde youe haue done mysdeede attrybuted vnto suffreth donne may lett withstande yt hym doth yt pryncypally youe beare ye praise tytle defendours lybertie grece yet neuerthelas great payne youe haue nowe caused assemblye made wol take thynges certayne holy orious youe wolle shal declare meanes iniuried necessary deliberate howe • shulde reuenge v wronges whyche hath donne vnto v athenyans dyd comme agaynste v oultrage v atoones lytle lytle although yet knowe thys assemblie wythout cause perceue welle thynke doynge youe shulde parceue yt slackenes bearyng whyche knowe youe whyche thynge shuld easely executed al one whych haue enterprysed whā shall see vnderstande passe yt wol execute yt much boldely wyth greater force nowe lordes lacedemonians youe arne reste woll resiste violēces force lēgth tyme abate strengthe enemy whā begynne increase tary vntyll dowbled thys y youe haue custome knowe medes came frome worldes ende agaynste werein lande bifore youe made prouisions might onght haue done bifore honnour suertie lett nought athenyans whyche farre youe euene youre neyghbours youe loue better shuld come assayle youe thā furst inuade thys meane put selfe hazart warre whā shalbe much stronger truly youe ought well consyder victory whyche agaynst stranger kynge medes great parte hys faulte chiefly athenyans whan warre agaynst v vaynquyshed thair errours committed valyantnes also youe ought remēber trustynge ayde fauour taken destroyed thynke speake thies thinges hatred haue agaynste sayd athenyans manner quarellinge parte frēde frende sheweth hys quarell playncte whan one doth othere whyche ought manner accusation complayne iniuries ennemys hath donne v truly people worlde whome laufull complayne themselues sorowe thair allyes confederate arne thinke marked specially fyght greate quarelles thynges greate ymportance wherof semeth v haue regarde woll consyder haue agaynste athenyans whyche ennemys people seke alwayes nouuelties also subtyll studye oute meanes increase themselues diligent execute touchynge thinke suffycient kepe togider haue wythoute enterpryse thynge also negligent execute though necessitie requyre thys meane see haue greater audacyte force put themselues many greate daungers againste opynion people neuertheles whatsoeuer harde thinge enterpryse haue good hope execute yt harte y much lessar enterpryse force execute yt wherby chaunceth enterpryses wythout dāger put doubte neuer thinke arne longe inough busynes furthermore diligente neglygence go contynually fourth thair countrey arne restfull thinke thair voyage welrecompense thair absence whan go countrey thinke whyche le • e behynd youe y loste whan haue vainquished thair enemy poursue thair victory lengthe whan ouercomed lose one iote couraige furthermore prouiding thinges whyche cōcerne weale thair cytie vse thair wytts counsayle thair owne cause thair bodyes sett haband onne strange people whome knewe whan fayle execute enterpryse thinke haue loste somuche thair owne also whan haue gotten thynge semeth lytle regarde thought alsayed thinge wherof bene frustrated thair hope parforced themselfe recouer suche losse newe enterpryse thynke effecte none haue hope togiders thinge enterpryse diligent execute thair enterprise also thies thinges vse thair lyfe thair age labour daungers withoute muche enioyinge thynges haue gottonne contynual desire haue gett thinke feaste thynge playsante whiche executed thynge whiche enterprysed repose men take necligence y dammageable parsone laborious exercise sort may wel said cōprehend fewe wordes borne wt wytt cannot rest suffer rest one cytie ennemye slepe lordes lacedemoniēs thinke may well reste whan necessary execute vertuously geue vnderstād woulde oultrage haue harte resiste youe mesure youre modestie equitie wille euille othere reuenge youe whan men would whyche thynge youe shall skarcely whan haue cytie neyghbour whych shalbe equall wyth nowe woll haue bifore declared lyue conuersant athenian accordinge thair aunciēt māners customes necessary haue regard ye thinges newe presente case busynes right conueniēt cytie y rest peace change hys lawes auncyent customes right whyche oppressed affaire necessary thinke many newe thynges imagynne many craftes resiste cause wherby athenyans alwayes inclyned enterprise new thinges muche greate experience haue wherfore lordes nedefull henceforwardes youe cease youre prolonging slackenes youe succour frendes specially potyde haue vnderstanded entre diligence landes athenyans suffer frendes parentes fall hande mortall ennemys also constrayned despayre seke allyaunce whyche may well thys case wythout reprehended goddes whome haue made othe also men shall vnderstande reasone wherfore shall haue done yt departe thair allyes beinge forsakenne arne reputed breaker faythe worthely whyche haue denyed succour whyche ye fourthwith delyuer v wyll parseuer faythfulnes owe youe doinge otherwyse shulde vnhappy also coulde recouer people haue greatly biloued v upō whych thynges may please youe take good counsayle good deliberation • yt may sayde gouerne countrey peloponese wyth iesser dygnytie reputation parentes dyd haue lefte youe thys gouernance manner spake corinthian nowe cytie lacedemonie certayne ambassadours athenyans whyche sente thider longe bifore matter vnderstandyng thies complainctes practises denised expedyēt thair honnor go towardes senate cytie aunswere complainctes made agaynst athenyans shewe generall oughte determyne vpon thynges bifore furst well digested vnderstande strengthe thair sayd cytie bringinge remembrance auncyent men thynges whyche knewe doynge yonge men vnderstande thynges wherof yet experience thought well whan lacedemonyans vnderstande thaire declaration wolde enclyned maigntaigne peace rather contynue • reste begynne warre sayde vnto lordes counsaylle come matter shewe thair plaisirs gaue audyence speake manner narration ambassabassadours athenian counsaylle lacedemonyans ☞the viii chapter cōme towne lordes lacedemonyās debate wyth allyes matter ye know yet vnderstandyng complaynctes othere cyties make agaynste willinge presente declare aunswere againste charge lay vnto v also arne iudges betwene v entente credite lyghtly whyche say agaynst v thair parsuation determyne slightly matter whyche greate importance otherwyse requisitt also woll well informe youe affaire dedes bee whyche holde haue laufully gottoneyt furthermore cytie y suche yt ought estemed wythout rehersynge thynges auncyent men haue knowlaige therof comon fame renomme true scyence wol speake doone warre medes warre haue afterwardes peace conuenyent graue prudent people lyue peace reste whan wronged violence done vnto euen conuenient vertuous couragyous people tourne peace warre whan oultraged haue wel prouyded theyr affayres come agayn peace accorde nother proud prosperitie victorye also couetyse peace reste suffre thēself oultraged muche loue reste nyce forcinge reuenge self parceyueth hym selfe sone depryued voluptuousnes taketh reste also parsone hath oftentymes good aduentures warre forgetteth hym selfe vnassured vnfaythfull fiercenes crueltie suche sorte thinketh ought oftentymes foolyshe enterpryses chaunce well ennemyes dyd conducte theyrs folyshly also manye enterpryses semed haue ben well begonne haue myshappened thynges suche matter neuer executed sorte purposed vpon also men haue alwayes good certayne hope thynges comme enterpryse whan cometh execute fayle oftentymes feare nowe touchyng v haue bene greatly oultraged athenyans purchase enterpryse warre vpon good iuste quarell intent lyue alwayes peace reste shall haue ben reuenged warre oughte hope haue victory many reason furste yt haue greater nomber people better warryours haue wyth one wyll delyberated shalbe commaunded v arne mighty shippes woll supplye aswell much particuler monney woll furnyshe euery one hys rate portion also syluer tēple delphos ye olimpus may coigne meanes shall easely wtdrawe reteigne maronniers also theyr men warre straungers mercenary huyred souldyours borne countrey thing otherwyse v mighty people monneye yt maye haue victorye ouer beleue shalbe discomfyted also howe much longer resiste muche people shall exercyse applye thēself sea muche people harte thā whan shall haue ben exercysed shalbe alwayes strong ye hardynes haue cometh vnto thē nature may acquyre get nother arte learnynge maye well exercyse acquyre industrie trauayle yt haue also shall fynde moneye ynough fournyshe thys affayre yf theyr allyes refuse paye trybute theyr seruytude subiectyon shall wretched refuse contrybute goodes reuē ge v oure ennemyes saue oure lybertye also whan shall haue taken v woll intreate v worse cause goodes haue parte many meanes make warre agaynste furst woll practyse theyr allyes subiectes woll cause rebelle agaynste thys meane woll cause lose reuenues haue also maye destroy theyr countreys territoryes whereby monney groweth vnto many occasyons meanes maye happen v wherof nowe take aduyse neuer warre made holy meanes accordyng preparatiō deuysed begynnynge self causeth others comme vnderstandyng men accordynge accydentes chaunces whiche occurre happen haue hygh entier courage greater suertie sadnes feare euery one v ought thincke imagyne yf questyon hys lymites boundes wyth hys neyghbours myghtye woulde suffre hym selfe oultraged presently athenyans myghtye ynough subdue v altogider whereby shall easely subdue v particularly towne • towne whiche thynge woll yf allye selues together resiste wyth one accorde yf haue victorye ouer v though thynge ryght heauy dyspleasante spoken yet alwayes heareth ought vnderstande victorye shalbe thynge oure bondage whiche thynge abhomynable harde named peloponese muche see effecte manye noble cytyes suppedytated trauaylled one onely cytye wherin semeth eyther nyce neglygent feare muche pacyent meane degenerating frome vertue glorye ancestres haue delyuered grece seruytude semeth suffycyente defende oure lybertye whan suffre one onely cytye vsurpe gouernemente ouer v whan one onely tyraunt cytye demaunde maye chased awaye consyder indurynge thys incurre thre greate euyll vyces wytt cowardnes pusillanymytie imprudence yt auaileth nothyng say excuse youe sayd vyces youe woll exchue temeritie rashnes whyche hath bene pernycious vnto many people excuse vnder shadowe wherof many haue bene deceyued ought rather feare named madnes sarueth nothinge oure purpose taxe reprehende thinges passed longer talke tyme requyreth ought prouyding succouring thinges presente trauaile cōme holde wherunto archidamus aunswered thys mannerthe aū • swer archidamus youe saye ryght well plateans yf dedes lyk • vnto wordes pausanyas graūted youe youe shulde lyue youre lybertye youre lawes euen • shulde haue ayded yourselues power haue kepte set agayne self lybertie grekes presente acte wherof youe speake parttakers daūgers warre aswel haue bene subdued brought seruytude athenyans occasyon wherof al thys armye assembled warre begonne wherfore much better youe shall kepe youre othe youe shall ayde restore libertye yf woll leaste lyue youe haue lyued heretofore laboure youre lande peace ☞the xv chapter youe lordes peloponesyans feareth come vnto battaille reasone loste groundeth feare nother wel vpon good cause preparation apparaille suche apperteigned menne thought come fight sea rather voyage onely cary transporte armye lande wherein inconuenyences chaunced vnto v whyche small mysfortune might partly ignorāce beinge furste tyme youe hadde fought sea wherefore knowinge consyderinge vainquished force vertue ennemys rather raysons ye cōtrary raisonable shulde nowe destitute couraige ought consider albeit oftimes men estymation faile lose fortune warre yet neuerthelas haue reteigne vertue hardynes harte iudge haue lost former faulte imprudentie likewyse neuer descouraiged tired touchinge parte truly though haue much knowlaige busynes sea ennemys haue yet haue asmuche hardynes vertue touchinge industrie whome youe feare accōpaigned hardynes yt shal know well execute great daungers shall haue learned excercise lackinge arte shall sarue nothinge feare taketh awaye memory arte without vertue harte couraige profiteth nothinge daungers wherfore behoueth somuche haue experyēce haue audacytie feare youe haue yt ye vainquished ye ought call remēbrance yt prepared disposed fight besides cōsider yt haue many ship thā ennemis shal fight ye sight army yt lande v pleasure reasone greatest nōbre best appoincted shuld haue better also parceyue one onely raisone wherby shuld haue fear fault heretofore haue done maketh v experience better instructed haue youe good courage aswell capytaines souldyars maronners euery one offyce without habandoninge forsakynge place wherinto youe arne ordeyned also duke heddes wol geue youe lesse cōmodytie fight thā y• shulde conducte battaile • also occasion example wery fayntharted shal shewe shalbe punyshed accordynge deserte likewyse shall shewe themself valyaunt shalbe recōpensed reputed according merytt vertue word declaratiōs animate encourage peloponesiās souldyars ye side phormio seing hys souldyars also afraide great nōber ship sawe caused likewise assemble comforted thē sor alwayes assured coulde comme againste one greate armye sea hable resiste themselues athenyans conceyued thys whiche declaration alcidus gaue lycence many prysonners yet chio place whyche hadde takenne ryghte easely wythout resistence whan didde see shippes vpon sea fledde awaye bifore came towardes thinkinge bene athenyans neuer thought athenyans kepinge sea shippes peloponesians euer durste passe ionū alcidus departed haste flyinge frome ephesus aduertised yet beinge ancre clarus sene discouered two ship comminge athene wyt salamyne paraleparala wherfore fearynge pursued armye sea athenyans went depthe sea intente approche lande good wille vntill arryued peloponese herof aduertised paches athenyans side specially one certayne messenger sente ethreus cytes ionū closed walles greate feare armye sea peloponesians passynge longe countrey though willinge arrest tary yet wold lande pillage afterwards tyme peloponesians last entred countrey athens great noise afreshe moued betwene comme newly inhabitt cytie auncyent cytezeins occasion wherof kepte towne forte • ied themselfe vpon walles hym wolde sende hym ayaine hoole saulfe wythin walle like dyd whan aryued bifore caused incontinently warded kepte wythout byndinge chayninge otherwyse afterwarde right soubdainely caused people wyth arrowes rendered cytie colophonyens beinge put fourthe taken parte wt medes afterwardes thathenyans founder cytie caused colophonyans founde obeyssance assemble themself togither sent inhabitte athens athenyans caused salethus incontinētly dye though promysed many thynges amonge siege whiche peloponesyans holde yet bifore platee shulde raysed othere prysonners matter beinge put deliberation counsaille yt greate anger determined cause dye onely thē thider brought also mytylenyens excepte wemen childrene frome foortene yeares downewarde whiche shuld sklaues bonde men estemed faulte sayd tokenne sayd mytylenyens hadde pourposed longe circumstance prouyded afore rebellyon dispatched galley signefy paches decree senate athene commaunde execute yt yet morowe abhorred repented themselues pytie doo putte youe daunger also youe gette good wylle ye consyder empyre youe haue y veray tyrannye obeye youe doo yt againste wylle also wolle longer obedyente youe pardonne taultes haue donne againste youe force feare haue youe make obeissant goodnes mercy vse towardes woorste see oure affayre y thys matter determynedde concludedde y fyrmenes stabilitie vnderstande y better gouernemente cytie vseth lawes fyrmely wythoute reuocation yea though euyll hath good lawes doth kepe inuiolablie ignorance wyth sobrenes grauitie woorth knowlaige wyth inconstancy rashenes people somwhat grosse slacke vnderstandinge doo admynistre well conducte better estate thā hable sharper wytted thies woll alwayes wyser lawes shewe matter wherof y questiō force eloquēce well speakynge knowe othere chapter prayse opynyon reproue thys men putt agayne deliberation matter mytylene thinke yt good men consulte many tymes vpon waightie affaire thinketh two thynges much contrary good connsaille wytt hedynes haste wrath anger one doth thinges folishly furyously rashly also thinkethe wyll empesche lett men shewe thinges woordes y wythoute vnderstandinge hath conceites deuyses wel knowin thinke yt thing come yet parceued may otherwise vnderstand wordes hath vnderstandinge woll perswade dishoneste euill matter thinketh cannot make good woordes wol astony choke iniuries villenies wyll saye contrary great signe affectith fauoureth matter yet blame charge againesayers wt corruption man obiecte againste whose opynyon greatest parte counsell haue alowed vnderstandeth well cause shalbe reputed onely ignorant noughty parsone whan obiected corrupted brybed though men allowe opynyon yet shall neuerthelas suspected holden shalbe onely reputed ignoraunte also noughty parsone whereby publique welthe shall susteigne dommaige people dare speake counsaille freely feare thereof semeth shuld better wealthe comon weale man cytie vnderstandynge knowlaige speke wel yt people lesse occasion offende whiche hoole contrary good cytezeine speaketh opynyon ought empesche feare shulde speake againste hym equalytie modestie shewe reasone hys opynyon better moreouer thinketh cytie gouerneth itselfe reasonne oughte nother honnour hym counsaillethe welle aboue othere yet lessen hym whyche hadde bifore likewyse shulde shame hym whose opynyon allowed yette lesse punishe meane whose iudgement shalbe found good shall care saye thynge whyche thinkethe sarue get honnour fauour people lyke raysons whose opynyon y approuedde shall moued chaunge yt gratefye multitude wherin clene contrarye anny maye charged haue bene subournedde brybed gyfte promes thoughe haue good opynyon counsailleth wealthe cytie yet throughe suspytion sayd corruption wherof none apparance wol reiecte forsake yt whatsoeuer thynge sayth yt good euil yt suspected wherfore necessarye wyll persuade thinge comunaltie aswell good euyll vse lye cautels wherby followith bicause thies disguysings chalenges man may proffytt shuld speke open manifeste matter except deceyue geue hym thynge openly shalbe suspectedde wyllynge gayne yt whyche raisonne yt y expedyente offyce haue charge delyberate determyne greate waightieste affayres shulde parceyue youe othere mynde thynges presente hande consyderedde specyally whych saye muste shewe raysonne youe heare v render accompte youe heare ordeynedde heareth suffreth himselfe perswaded shuld asmuch punyshedde speakethe perswadethe cetaynelye youe shulde iudge wyth modestie raysonne whan matter desperate vnto youe youe punyshe throughe anger wrathe hym onely hath geuen counsell youe yt haue followed yet doinge youe trespasse asmuche hath spokenne yt touchinge intend speake fauour mytyleniens speake againste accuse parsonne good wyttes resteth questyō mysdede alonly consulte well selues albeit appereth vnto v haue trespassed yet woll counsaille shalbe put dethe except expedyente v likewise merytte haue grace wolde opynyon shulde extended vnto excepte might profytable vnto v forsomuche oure consultation haue regarde vnto tyme come tyme passed cleon hath said requisitt wythstand rebellyōs fromthesfourth follow thies shulde punyshedde suche pretense rebellyons thoughte mighte acheue neuer cytie rebelled thoughte haue greater force greater preparatyon yt hadde itselfe frendes allyes naturall thing men offend neuer law rigoroux yf sence haue bene ennemyes hath bene defaulte whan inuaded thebayns perseuerynge amytye allyaunce furst recours vnto youe youe repoulsed v saiynge youe farre frome v shewed v shulde haue recourse athenian whiche oure nyghe neyghbours lyke neuer warre youe suffred oultrage arne youe suffre v yf hadde bene wyllynge haue departed frome athenyans yet done iniurye consydered ayded v agaynste thebayns youre commodytye bene honnestye v caste vp forsake seynge chiefly oure requeste receyued v theyr allyaunce also haue receyued greate benefittes receyued v theyr burgeoses wherfore reasonable yt shulde obey wyth power yf youe whiche duke capytains youre partyes haue done euyll thynge hauynge allyes compaignie ought imputed thē haue followed capytaynes haue conducted touching thebayns besydes many oultrages done dyd cō mytt last agaynst v hath bene cause euylls youe knowe came tyme peace vpon daye solempne feaste inuade cytye wherby receyued suche punyshment deserued lyke laufull v permytted commone lawe generall saufgarde vsed amonge people whiche laufull euery man sley hym commeth assaulte hym ennemye wherfore yf woll punyshe v cause shulde agaynste iustyce youe shulde declare youre selfe euyll iudges yf make youre proffyte yt youre allyes thys warre youe woll iustice theyr pleasure haue regarde vnto youre proffyte reasone howesoeuer ye woll haue regarde vnto youre vtilitie consyder haue bene proffytable vnto youe thys affayre yet haue bene muche onelye vnto grece whan youe muche greater dangier thys presente youe haue bothe harte puyssance assaulte stranger thebayns thinge shall youe depryue v youre ancesters parentes honnors haue leue lande theire ennemyes haue slayne moreouer bringe seruytude land whiche grekes haue recoueredde lybertie also shall leue naturall ennemys aduertysinge youe selfe daye wherein daunger suffre extreme euyll y onely wherein dydde manye fayre actes wyth ancestres forsomuche people suche myserye necessytye bee y myserable allyance chiefly made betwene youe medes wherof youe make great buckler defence whyche also bene suffycient defende agaynst v wolde haue wronged wherfore wythoute doubte youe haue wyllingly chosen youe youreselfe confesse ye arue comme wronge othere yet neuerthelas lesse dishonneste rendre saruyce pleasure like case one oughte good reasone iustice onelye wylle acquite euille vniuste quareile islande ¶ howe sycilians perswation hermocrates made peace among themself sente agayne frothence athenyans ☞the viii chapter sommer countreye sycile treuese made furste betwene camerins gelians sone cyties countrey ambassadours sente gele treate thappoynctement betwene manye opynyons hadde bene spokenne dyuers contrary one othere whyche euerye one dydde speake hys particuler intereste makynge oration hermocrates cytie lordes sycilians whyche leaste countrey also y muche trauailled wythe warre wherefore whych shall say y owe haue feare warre othere onely y shewe semethe vnto common welth countrey albeit recyte vnto youe displeasure tourmente warre y thynges thereby arne wonte happene y man canne welle expresse though vsed longe talke yet somuch man lacke vnderstandynge knowlayge y constraynedde enter hedlyng also none wolle refrayne make thynketh thereby gett feare yll maye come therof chanceth ryghte oftene whyche enterpryse yt hope thereby wynnynges wolle regarde difficultie daungers thereof consyder moste inconuenyences loue better hazarte whyche maye happene presently susteygne payne dāmage yet nothere one othere canne obteigne whyche hope throughe benefytte ayde tyme wherelore thynke speake appoynctemente y thynge conuenyente menne specyallye v thys saysonne well aduysedde heretofore euerye one haue enterpretysedde warre thynkynge therby make proffytte prouyde hys affayre oughte nowe whyche warre stryues assaye comme agayne peace wherein cannot meane recouer euerye one whyche apperteigneth vnto maye afterwardes retourne warre thynke good muste vnderstande bee discreate prudente thys assemblie y made pryncypally knowe oure particular questyons rather deuyse maye saue wythdrawe countrey sycille handes athenyans fantasie deceyue v goo aboute subdue v consyder whan shalle knowe youre faultes whyche doo hope dailly doo laye wayte thoughe comme hyder good fellaushipp allyance yet trouthe intreate v ennemylike go aboute nothynge particuler proffytt doo chose amytie wythe theym yett comme readelye vnto theire succoures haue made allyance wyth theym wyllyngly wyth yet neuerthelas sayd athenyans pardonned arne blamed go aboute encrease estate seignyorie vnderstandethe thies thynges whosoeuer shall knowe common feare oughte eschewedde general common prouysion deceyueth hymselfe greately agree oureselues togider shall veray easely brynge oureselues bene called v beynge honestly comme euyl intente shal retourne reasonablie frustrated purpose thys whyche saye vnto youe touchynge athenyans haue wylle counsaille well wyll fynde good concerning peace daunger athenyans longe tyme hadde nott greate garnysons countrey thought puissance bene greate parceyuedde afterwardes experyence • also thies people haue accustomed conduct affayres disordered affectyon rather reason prouydence puttynge esperaunce whyche wylled followed yt wythoute annye greate purpose effecte thynge whyche wylledde reprouedde vnder coloure reasone also grounded themself greately vpon losse whyche athenyans made frankly beoce occasyon whereof semedde coulde soo soone sende succour quarter perswasyons brasidas dydde theym vnderstande sayd athenyans durste fyghte againste hym nygh nysee though hadde thys • mie thies reason vpon thies ymagynations ioyous presente lybertie vnder protection lacedemonyans whome thoughte hauynge newely made enterpryse quarter fully determyned followe power othere syde athenyans consyderinge daunger sente fourthwyth succour sayde quarter kepe defende lande although wynter tyme also brasidas hadde wrytton vnto lacedemonye shuld sende vnto succour meane tyme woulde cause made asmanye shyppes coulde ryuer strymone lacedemonyans sende succour aswel occasyō discorde princypallest cytie also people desired recouer prysonners lacedemonyans ☞the xv chapter begynnynge furste vere sprynge tyde athenyans made trefues wyth lacedemonyans one yeare athenyans dyd thynkynge durynge season brasidas wold haue practysed wythdrawe landes meane tyme haue fortefyed also hopynge treate durynge tyme fynall peace yf parceyuedde shulde good lacedemonyans also perswaded themselfe sayd athenyans feared sayde matter lyke trewe hauynge meane trefues repose release trauailes paynes wherin bene • woulde enclyned peace doynge would render prysonners whiche kept whych thyng sayd lacedemonyans desired hoped obteigne yt makinge trefues duringe tyme brasidas prosperedde longe warre contynued dyd gette ennemys hopedde sayde people shulde releasedde delyuered trefues concluded thys fourme athenyans dyd delyuer article whych demaūded lacedemonyās made aunswere suche foloweth fourme trefues bitwene athenyans peloponesyans furst woll touchynge temple oracle apollo pythicus l • efull wyl aither partie go thider wythout fraude wythout feare haue counsaile god manner accustomedde thys article approued lacedemonyans allyes promysed myghte beotyans phociens shulde approue ratefie cause sent herault vnto secondarely touching treasure god whych pillaged imbecilled woll men procede againste transgressours punishe accordinge theire demerittes lyke hath bene accustomedde suche case youe wylbe comprysed trefues shalle obserue auncyent ordonances customes touchynge matter thys aunswered lacedemonyans theire allyes contente peace made aither party shulde contente wythe lande lyke presently dyd holde yt wytt lymitts lacedemonyans shuld quarter coryphasius bytwene bufrades tomeus ye athenyans cytheis one myght make allyaunce wyth othere whych nysea mynoa shuld passe way leadeth pylus vnto temple neptune tēple temple whyche leadeth mynoa whyche way also nother megaryans myght passe wtin island ye athenyās taken one shuld haue cōmunicatyon marchandyse matter others athenyās myght vse present trezena landes remayned vnto treatie theire pleasure also myghte goo sea vnto theire landes frendes pleasure concerninge lacedemonyās myght sayle wyth longe shypps go sayle wyth galley shypps go wyth oares portage fyue hoūdred talentes item heraults ambassadours might go wtoute empeschemēts wt suche compaigny wold aswel lāde peloponesians athenyans aswel sea lande treate thappoinctment item none nother enterteigne obeysance yf haue victorye shalbe woorse estate byfore warre bigonne parte farre vnderstāde affaire sicille semeth syracusains although obteigne principalitie countrey yet hatefull nother hurtful vnto v poyn • wherupon egestians grounde themself paraduēture present come towardes lacedemonyans gratetie thē yet notwithstanding beleued haue estate lose wille quarelle strange empire enterpryse warre agaynste maye welle thynke whan peloponesians shall haue ayde destroied extinguished estate empire wylle also afterwardes destroy moreouer grekes whiche countrey maruaylous feare v longe yett shalbe greater yf shalle shewe theyme oure armye viewe afterwardes withdrawe enter countrey receyue anye shame damage wylle esteme v rather wolle ioigne theymeselfe wyth grekes comme assaylle v oure countrey youe knowe welle thynges somuche greater admiration men frome theyme somuche haue lesser esteminge reputacion approued knowin lyke may sene selues hauing victorye agaynste lacedemonyans peloponesians great feare resist power nowe already esteme litle presume go cō quere sycille though ennemyes wisely done man ought extole take tomuche courage aduersitie hys ennemy rather refrayning courage glorye trust hys puissance also ye ought consyder lacedemonians shame haue receiued v study thing may cause v comytt folly meane wherof myght reuenge shame recouer honor somuche couetouse glory vertue people lykewyse lordes ought consider questiō moued egestains stranger sycilians howe shall kepe self cytie whiche gouerneth self small nomber people ennemy gouerned generaltie also ought thynke haue smalle respite one great warre greuous malady whiche maye brynge v greate sorowe encreased nomber people wyth ryches shoulde kepe employe ourselues thies bannysshed men repare vnto v haue succour haue spokenne fayer haue lyed danger neyghbours consideredde geue v nothynge wordes ayde haue victory maye seme good vnto mocke v euill acknowlaige saruice shall haue done chaunce otherwyse shall brynge v ruyne destruction • one hath bene chosene consent haue charge armye parswadeth enterpryse hys particuler proffytt paraduenture youth desyreth haue hermocrates didde speake people camaryne assembled purpose thys manner presence ambassadours athene oration hermocrates camerins sente hither vnto cameryus doubte haue ye afrayde thys army athenyans feare leaste artificiall subtille woordes hauinge bene v aduertised shulde induce allure purpose whyche vnder coulour whiche youe haue parceyued thinge suspecte ryght certeine come restore set leontins house rather chase v oute beleue dryue grece cyties come hider sett agayn countrey chased nother haue great care saie leontins cousin chalcydes seing self chalcydes thies descendedde theym broughte seruytude bondage rather vnder coulour wherby haue obteigned wold presently obteigne coūtrey thies party voluntarely chosen capitains tharmy grekes resiste medes ye ionian colony allyāce haue reduced broughte obeissance vnder colour yt forsakē tharmy wtout lycence occasion warrs questiōs amongest themself vnder suche coloures finde purpose whan dyd see oportunitie suche maner may sayd trouth athenyans made warre agaynste medes lybertie grece grekes enioye owne rather dyd make intent grekes shulde sarue medes self grekes change lorde change ruled moste stronge ruled weakely onely imagined moste euil shuld gouerne hym intended beste albeit cytie athene greately worthye reprehension reproche yet come hyder procure people whych knowe ynough wyll rather rebuke v syciliens whyche haue oure eye example cyties grece haue subdued yet notwithstanding thynke defende ourselues nother reiecte caste fallaces sophemes wolde delyuer v wytte come ayde leontins cowsins egestains allyes wherfore thinketh shulde sooner thinke case doo knowe ionyens hellespontyns islander whyche haue alwayes accustomed subiects medes also change lorde whosoeuer handes fail doriens free nation come oute peloponese whyche franke countrey inhabyting sycille ought abyde vntill taken towne town knowynge thys onely meane maye taken cause haue prepared themself meane goo separate set v asonder practice vnder colour alliance set warre speakynge gracyous ioyful word euyll maye vnto v accordinge shall fynde occasion one amonge v perswadeth euil cometh next neyghbour yet farre frome hym shall remayne wtout coming whome athenyans ennemyes well syracusains meane shuld follie put part dangier saue myne say vnto vnderstandeth well ought consider y• defending myne defendeth owne propre asmuch myne somuche doth assuredly aduantage hath cō paigny destroyd may helpe hym also whosoeuer hath suche fantasie ought consyder athenyans comme reuenge themself syracusains ennemytie haue rather vnder coulour herof confirme amytie youe enuieth v feareth v custome puissant alwaies enuyed feared feoble therfore semeth receyue dammage shalbe moore tractable gracious neuertheles shall remaine suertie trulye trustethe thinge power hys intente wylle men haue fortune power euen haue wyll therfore happene otherwyse thynketh whyche hath suche fantasie peraduenture grief euyll shall come vpon himselfe shall desire tyme enioye good lyke hath done tyme shalbe impossyble hym sithens shall haue forsaken refused wt dangiers fortune asmuche hys myne name worde effecte aydeth v affaire name defendeth estate effecte defendeth hys oune trulye reasone wolleth well ye camerins neighbour self dāger wherein shulde consyder thies thinges ought haue cōme allyance readely ye haue done owne good comforte admonishe v shulde lose oure coura • ge thinge mighte chaunce v alleage declare vnto v selfe thynges ye woolde haue alleaged athenyans surst come youe whyche thynge ye haue yet done yf ye woll say youe woll kepe vse reasone somuche towardes v towardes oure ennemyes feare offende one take youre occasyon vpon allyance whyche youe haue wyth truly ye haue made allyaunce go assaylle youre frendes pleasure appetite rather onely succour one dyd come assaille youe thys cause rhegins though chalcydes haue bene willinge ioygne wyth thies restore leontins house chalcydes wythout hauing reasonable excuse haue iustification proufe well couloured athenyans suspected gouerned themself herin wysely woll hauinge reasonable cause excuse youe beare fauour proffitt vnto naturelly • ure ennemyes habandone forsake whyche youre neyghbours parentes ioygne youresel • vnto thies certainly ye shall agaynste reasone yf ye woll ayde thys puissance enemyes ye ought rather feare although ioigned vnited togider shulde haue cause feare iustly separate deuyde oureselues one whiche thinge attempte power come thys countrey onely agaynste v rathere agaynste yet haue done agaynste v whyche wylledde though dydde vaynquishe v battaille victorie wente fromthence wherefore may clerly knowin whan shalbe ioigned togiders ought greately care chiefly attendyng succour come peloponesyans whyche better warryours thies truly yt ought seme anny good youe busye youreselfe meddle nother theym v shalbe reasonable touching v consyderinge ye allyed togyder also suertie though ryght furste sight lyke egall betwene v concernynge reason abouesaide yet dede y greately dyuers agaynste warre y made fault haue bene succoured vainquished vainquishors ouercommers thynge maye sayde absence one hath bene ouercomed haue bene prohybited left euyll therfore lordes shalbe muche better done ayde whome men wolde oppresse whiche parentes neyghbours defending comon welth sycille suffer athenian offende meddle wyth nother partie shewe fewe wordes woll saye insomuche nede many wordes declare ye vnderstande praye require youe ayde v thys present busynes protest youe ye shal suffre v wasted destroyed ionyens perpetuall ennemyes doryens ye habandone forsake v noughtly vaynquyshed athenyans shalbe youre faulte shalle haue glorye victory touchynge huyer rewarde shalbe none othere hath geuene victorye ouercomme ye shall suffer payne ye haue bene cause dangeire shall haue bene consider whole chose ye presently aythere incurre submit seruitude presented without danger ouercommynge thys people eskape wyth v beinge subiectes also right longe tyme ennemyes hermocrates thus spokene euphemus athenyan arose vp dydde speake thys manner ¶ oration euphemus athenyan camerins ☞the xv chapter comme hider lordes camerins onely renewe ancyent amytie allyāce haue sithens syracusaine hath charged maliciously spoken agaynst v nedefull speake empire howe good iuste cause reasone haue obteygned whereof thys hath spoken beareth good wytnes hath said ye ionyens haue al way ben enemy doriens muste vnderstande truly ionyens peloponesyans doriens greater nomber neyghbours haue trauailled kepe oureselues shulde bringe v subiection cause warre medes hauinge army sea wythdrewe ourselfe empire conducte lacedemonyans capytaines armye grece reasonable shulde vnder vnder v haue bene puissant consequently beinge made prynces superiours grekes tyme subiectes vnto medes haue kepte maignteigned oure reygne knowynge whan shall haue asmuche puissance resyste force shall nothynge bounde vnto speke clerely haue vpon good cause brought obeissance subiection ionyans islander though oure parentes syracusains say thys cause came wyth medes agaynste cytie whyche metrip olitaine whence descended feare losynge house domestycall goodes hadde hardynes forsake townes cyties conserue kepe lybertie dyd rather loued better bondemen subiectes medes saue goodes also comme wyth agaynste v brynge v self seruytude bondage thies reason haue well deserued haue seignyorye rule ouer also trouthe wythoute anye difficultie fournished warre ship shewed harte courage cyties grece chiefly desarued haue rule dominyon ouer y• ionyens vnto v euyll coulde beynge ioygned wyth medes wherefore desire encrease force agaynst peloponesians vnder conducte charge others truly desarue haue obteigne empire lordeshyppe whyche alone chasedde awaye medes leaste generall lybertie haue taken susteigned dangier aswell specyally moreouer lawfull without reproche euery man serche welth meanes may cause wherfore come hider vnto youe knowing also whyche demande y asmuche proffytable youe v shew wherfore thies blame v wherof wold make youe afrayde knowe well feare haue suspytion anny thynge ready perswade begynninge swete woordes afterwardes whan cometh dede busynes fynd beste effecte kepe enterteigne oure empyre authorytie feare haue sayde cause comme hydere conserue oure frendes putte theym subiectyon seruytude defende othere shulde brynge theym men shulde abalshed haue made greatte armye ayde defende frendes nother ought yt said wold make great coste thynge touchethe v lytle doo repute thinke whan ye shalbe power resiste syracusains oure estate shalbe muche moore suertie peloponesyans shall haue somuche lesse succour frō syracusains principall thing whyche youre allyaunce amytie saruethe whyche also reasonable conuenyente leontyns restoredde sette agayne theyr howses subiectes parentes eubeyans puyssante susteigne warre agaynste syracusains v puyssance ynoughe oureselfe susteigne warre grece agaynste oure neighbour chalcydes oure subiects thys syracusaine blaymeth v sayinge bileued wyllinge sette agayne lybertie thies holdynge othere subiectyon shall sarue v well exemptynge theym frome delyuerey men warre shalle fournyshe v wyth monney lykewyse leontins shalle ayde v thys countreye sycille oure allyes frendes chifly whyche lyue lybertie muste vnderstande man ruleth tyrannye cytie hath empire repute nothinge dishoneste maye proffytable vnto theym estemeth nothynge hys hathe good suertie thynges reputeth othere hys frendes hys ennemyes accordynge chance occurrantes tymes affayres nowe shulde proffytte v thys present anoye frendes rather enterteigne power authorytie intent oure ennemyes may thereby feoble thys ye may ought bileue fourme lyuinge vse oure otherallyes grece intreate parceue moste proffit witte chio mantinea take ship reste leaue lybertie handle rygorously constrayne paye v monney treate symply frendes allyes subiects maner thing although islander also easy subdue nigh peloponese meane lye opene inuasions wherfore whych men may beleue wol proffit chiefly woll make strōge kepe feare syracusains would subdue youe siciliās thing hoped obteigne force orels lacke whiche youe shulde haue people chance shulde retourne wythout doynge thing whyche thinge wherfore attempte go aboute brynge v suspytion wyth youe shall happene take theire partie shall haue meane passe thies party seynge theym puyssante wythout v shalbe tomuche puissante say semeth man true apparāce ther manyfest first time ye sente v demāde succour ye alleaged none feare came succour syracusains wolde subdewe wherby afterwards shulde danger wherfore suffre induced perswaded perseuer allyāce reason chiefly haue alleaged whan ye required take suspition comme greater armye sea puissant thies thinge vnreasonable ra • ye oughte muche haue suspytion thies v ye know well canne tarye wythoute youe though wold euyll vngracyous brynge oure frendes oure subiection yet coulde kepe aswell nauigation farre grece hither also • ere muche difficultie kepe youre cyties sycille whiche greate also haue manye people mayne lande touchinge thies feared youe somuche hoste feared hoste people whyche grosse whereby beynge youre neyghbours ye alwayes danger wayte youe contynuelly ready occasion ouerronne sett vpon youe lyke haue already declared towardes many sycilians newelye agaynste leontyns yet presentlye hauynge audacytie encouraige youe agaynste v whyche comme hyther kepe theyme frome doynge subduynge sycille thinkynge youe farre oute youre wyttes youe woolde geue faythe vnto tromperies deceitts • exhorte youe welth muche truly certenlye prayinge youe ye lose proffitt ye maye haue one v ye woll well chose whyche ye maye beste truste aboue consyder thies people haue euerye houre meane subdue youe wythoute ayde multitude theire people ye shall haue oftentymes meane chastise brynge downe kepe theym vnder suche ye haue present hauing succour frends allyes • ye suffre retourne wythout thing repoulsed sente away beaten truly tyme wyll come shall wishe haue one lesser party whā shall proffitte youe nothing ende youe othere syciliens creditt slander charge doo falselye laye agaynste v ryght wyllinge cy • painte declare wyth trouth cause wherefore men woolde brynge v suspytion praying hauing heard vnderstanded somarely ye vouchesafe also regarde marke theyme wolle denie rule gouerne neighbour touching ye sycilians defende shulde subdewed fearyng afterwards endāmaged thē shalbe lord ouer howe muche landes haue kepe somuch regarde constrayned haue affaire cause come time ye voyage haue made quarter defēde saue harmeles yt shuld oppressed fre wil proper motion prayer requeste wherfore youe thys present iudges arbitratours dedes although ryght harde youe euene presente iudge thereupon ought caste repoulse v rather herof make youre proffytte ye parceyue youe maye doo consider thynge shall damage egally vnto shall brynge proffytt vnto manye grekes wythoute damage throughe puissance whiche haue readye succoure reuenge opppessedde thoughe oure subiectes lye wayte theyme woulde theyme violence wronge forced forbeare lyue reste meane whiche doubte oultraged wrongedde suertie wythoute annye expense therefore lordes forsake suertie whiche comon whiche shoulde oppressedde necessarye presente youe rather wyth oure ayde render syracusayns whiche haue done bryngynge theyme agayne vnto equalitie neyghbours sette vpon theyme sharpely hauynge oportunytie ye alwayes payne defende youe frome theyme thus dyd euphemus speake nowe cameryns suche disposition tyme louedde athenyans woulde wyllynglye haue takene parte suspectedde wyllynge trouble vsurpe empire sycille touchynge syracusayns althoughe hadde hadde difference variance oftymes wyth theyme nygh neyghbours yet selfcause hadde sente vnto theyme people horseman intente hadde hadde victorye shoulde haue reprochedde theyme afterwardes bene done wythout also tyme comynge wyllynge ayde theyme rather athenyans thoughe smally athenyans hadde hadde victorye shewe estemed sayed syracusains lesse bene vainquisshed hadde consultedde debatedde matter amongest theyme made vnto theyme bothe one selfe aunswere egall asmuche one wytt warre betwene thē allyes determined breke othe one nother geue ayde vnto aither party vpon thys aunswere ambassadours departedde fromethence thies enterfaictes syracusains made preparasions coulde • warre • ouchynge athenyans wyntredde naxe neuerthe • practised al meanes cyties sycille drawe theym partie whereof great partie chiefly platt countrey subiectes syracusains rebelled franke free cyties mayne lande allyed theymself incontynently athenian sent theym succour monney men victuailles woulde doo free wyll constrayned auctorytie hath alwayes remayned amonge v durynge haue oftymes bene constrayned followe time neuerthelas haue contynually takene payne moderate refrayne lycence audacytie woulde fourme reasone conduct order thynges wylle haue alwayes bene tyme paste yet presently men haue seduced comon people perswading vnto woorst whiche haue chased dryuene away although tyme haue auctorytie haue alwayes counsailledde perswaded good thinges learned best ende conserue citie lybertie prosperitie lyke haue founde haue knowlaige comon estate knowe yet haue al wayes despised abhorred yt knowe therof towardes youe therefore wyll nowe speake affaire whereupon ye ought presently deuyse wherein vnderstande annye thynge youe whereof nedefulle aduertise youe ye shall therein pronounce iudgemente gone whiche though departed fromethence duke capytaynes woll put execution withstande perceyue nothyng maye empesche insomuche syciliens accustomed warre yet neuerthelas whan ioigned alll togiders maye presence hym shalbe enterteigne youre amytie thys presente constrayne youre frendes shall haue doyng hope wauerynge doubte shall haue lesser feare comme youre allyance moreouer ye ought openly begyn warre athenynans doinge syracusayns shall knowe ye care myndefulle affaire occasion whereof shall take couraige resist athenyans shall haue lesser meane sende succour people whiche bene also thynketh ye oughte take fortefye soubdainely wyth walles towne de • elea whiche terrytorye athens insomuche • thyng athenyans feare yet neuerthelas onely towne wherof parte hath bene touched durynge warre truly man cannot endomage hys ennemye greatly doo vnto hym whiche perceyueth feareth bileued euerye man knoweth feareth thinges may preiudiciall hurtfull vnto hym therfore wolle geue vnderstande proffytt shalbe enclosyng sayd towne walles dommage shall bryng vnto ennemyes also shewe onely waighty therof sommarely fewe woordes whan ye shall haue fortefied place wtin lande many townes shall rendre themself vnto also ye shall take easely moreouer reuenue whiche perceyue mynes syluer laurium reuenues taken aswell lāde iurisdictiō shall ceasse specially leuie frendes perceiuing come againste v youre strength wille praise v smally thinges power cause come readely effect yf woll yt thinke erre matter may easely done none ought blame nother repute euill hauyng bene hertofore great ennemy chief capytaine oure people come speake nowe bitterly comon weale countrey nother also suspect preseume whiche say acquire gett fauour bicause bannishment exiled trouth malice naughtynes theym hate shall domage ye woll bileue ought repute youe thys present somuche ennemyes sometime ennemyes haue endomaged v haue constrayned frendes ennemyes nowe oultraged wronged whan auctorytie ouer people wherfore chased coūtrey recoen longer mine rather thinke y• laboure rather recouer whiche mine ought truly reputed louer countrey whiche desire hath recouer yt doth canne retourne thider beinge vniustly chased fromethence dare goo inuade yt whyche reason repute selfe suche lordes lacedemonyans whome • ye ought sarue yourselues danger trauailes knowe y comon prouerbe beinge ennemye doth endomage becometh frende • may also proffyt somuche knowe affaire athens also well nygh vnderstande coniecture therefore requyre youe insomuche question thinges great importance greue enterpryse reyse leuye twoo armyes one sea go sycille lande go countrey athens doyng ye may small puissance atteigne great thynges sycille clerely subuerte puissance athenyans aswell present come whereby estate shalbe herafter bothe whole suertie also ye shall haue superyorytie ouer grece constraincte wyllyngly alcibiades hadde thus spokene lacedemonyans wythout already purposed make warre agaynst athenyans though capytayns also souldyars wherefore seyng sycille conspyrethe nowe agaynste v looke newe succour oute peloponese ayther determyne calle v agayne home consyderedde moore weake oure ennemyes euen estate skatered abroad one parte followed clearchus sailled delos y• retourned mylet sone come agayne said clearchus came lande hellespontehellespō • tus tenne shipps whiche bifore arriued sayde hellespont caused cytie tourne confederation whereof athenyans whiche samie beinge sone aduertysed sente nō ber ship warde defende hellesponte light battaill bifore byzance wytt eyght shippes like nomber peloponesians meane tyme chiefz army athenyans principally thrasibulus always bene aduyse alcibiades ought called home agayne also sithens estate athens changed meane alwaies muche purpose declared suche sorte perswaded souldyars whyche agrede restoringe sayde alcibiades decree concluded put wrytinge whyche sayde alcibiades pardonned shulde called home agayne cytie whyche beynge published thrasibulus wente vnto tyssaphernes broughte alcibiades wyth hym samie hopynge hys meane wythdrawe sayde tyssaphernes amytie athenyans alcibiades beinge arryued samie caused people assemble proponed declared vnto many greate loss damaiges whiche su • teigned bannishement afterwardes speake profoundely highly wyttely affayres comon welth suche sorte put greate hope set vp agayne magnefyinge greatly auctoritie whiche hadde wt said tissaphernes ende auctorytie adm •• nistration athene shuld feare meane cōspiraties confederation shulde dissolued • weakened also samie shulde conceyue haue truste hym consequente myghte reputation ennemyes shulde mistruste sayde tyssaphernes lose hope whiche ayded sayde sayd athenyans samie tyssaphernes promysed hym paye wage souldyars yf might finde take suer truste vntill ende affayres though shulde therefore sell asmuche worth wold cause come succour ayde phenicians shyps already aspendus stede sendyng thēto peloponesyans ye assurance demaūded shulde receyue take agayne ye said alcibiades hauing declared suche lyke wordes capytains souldyars adioigne adde hym nōber chiefz army dyd geue auctorytie order thyngs effect toke great confidence hope made maner doubte welth nother ruyne fall foore houndred also ready euen selfe tyme vpon confydence whyche sayde saille pyreus wythout hauynge regarde enemyes nighe though many made greate instance obteygne yet wolde consente therunto saying expedient hauing ennemyes nyghe saille pyreus sithens geuen charge warre vnto hym made chief wolde prouyde euery thynge wyth tyssaphernes towardes whome retourned incontynētly departure assemblie shewe declare vnto woolde communicate consulte wyth thinges said tissaphernes great auctorytie athenian chief ende myght moore estemed shuld vnderstande meane might ayde hurt also happened therin euen vnderstode yt fauour tissaghernes helde athenyans feare feare self tissaphernes whan peloponesians mylet vnderstode repeale callinge home agayne made alcibiades hauynge already great suspytion agaynst begon blame openly trouth refused saylle encounter armye sea whyche come presente battaill euen mylet caused said tissaphernes colde paye soulde wage sayd armye togiders wt alcibiades right longe tyme trauailled laboured cause come difference dissention said peloponesians thys bruyt beinge come vp warryours mylet begonne assemble thē self trowpes done byfore time make great mutyne sedytion amōgest men auctorytie saying neuer entier paiment also • ne litle bene paid contynued threatened yt •• ey brought parte aither fight haue syracusains thuriens lesse subiected made greatest instance wyth sharpe prycking wordes haue payment u • whome astyochus made rude aunswere hermocrates willinge speake men maingteigne quarelle lifted vp staff whiche helde stryke parceyued maroners souldyars syracusains ronne impytuous • ye furiously vpon ye said astiochus perceiuing cōming wtdrew franchise sanctuary chapell therby meane saued sea hellesponte ☞the xv chapter armye athenyans locked poynctes extended coaste s • e towardes mayne lande syde peloponesians perceyuynge come forwardes departed abyde encounter whā party see nedefull fight extended themself sea wytt lacedemonyans xlviii shypps enlarged themself frō abyde dardane ryght poyncte whereof syracusayns myndarus helde lefte wherin lightest shyps athenyans extended themself towardes cheronese frō idaque archiane whiche al foore skoore sixtene shyps left poyncte whereof thrasyllus thrasybulus ryght capytaynes euery one place appoyncted hym peloponesians auaunced theymself fyghte furst geue assault ende haue enclosed left poyncte ryght poynct athenian myght suche sorte shulde haue bene hable enlarge theymselfe sea shyppes whyche myddeste shoulde constrayned retyre lande whiche verye farre whereupon athenyans perceyuynge frome coaste ennemyes woulde comme enclose assaulted theyme lyuely hauynge takene charge sea saylled gouernedde shyppes galiardly othere otheresyde leafte poyncte bene passed already rockye place whyche called sepulchre doggethe sepulcre dog meane whereof shyppes myddeste battaylle remayned nakedde disseparated frome two poynctes somuche greater danger ennemyes hadde nombere shypps farre better fournysshed wyth men moreouer rockye place sepulchre dogge extendeth alongest sea suche sorte wythin goulphe retreatte therof coulde see nothing whyche done wythoute thys cause peloponesians seynge separated feobled suche sorte came geue charge vpon theyme repoulsed theyme vnto lande peloponesians seynge theymeselfe haue vyctorye greate nomber theyme landed followe athenyans whyche coulde succouredde people wytte ryght poyncte wyth thrasibulus oppressed wyth greater nomber shyppes nothere wyth whyche left poynct wyth thrasillus coulde see dyd cause rockye place promontorye bitwene moreouer hadde muche resiste shyps syracusains greate nomber whyche oppressed greatly vntill peloponesians perceiuing themself haue victorye bigonne putt themself disorder followe ennemyes shipps skattered themself abroade thrasybulus perceiued wythout contending saille bifore russhed wyth ship strength vpon put flight fyndynge whiche brokene myddeste hys battaylle disorder brought feare many without tarying put themself flyght whiche parceyued siracusains othere wyth whyche bene already greatlye oppressed thrasillus dyd lykewyse putt themselfe flighte suche sorte armye peloponesians fledde straight towardes ryuer pydia fromethence towardes abyde albeit athenyans dyd take greate nomber ennemyes shippes yet vyctorie dyd come wel purpose bifore tyme greate feare peloponesians sea cause many loss whiche made many place wyth aboue sicille wherby victorie feare cessed whiche said peloponesyans sea also
